body:
Thanks, @zoltanmihaly for opening this issue:
I can reproduce this bug based on your code and confirm that this is a bug. 

Comment for future development during fix:
Most probably a problem a similar that was described in this issue: https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues/4538
We have to differentiate "range" vs "not range" date_input to be able to set the initial value correctly.

DEMO APP: [![Open in Streamlit Cloud](https://static.streamlit.io/badges/streamlit_badge_black_white.svg)](https://issues.streamlitapp.com/?issue=gh-5571)

Any news about this?

I found that setting the value of the `date_input` widget through the session state does not work also when passing only a single value. Instead, if the value is set through the widget argument, everything works fine.

Reproducible example:
```
import datetime

import streamlit as st


if __name__ == "__main__":

    st.session_state["date_input"] = datetime.datetime.strptime("2022-01-01", "%Y-%m-%d")

    st.date_input(
        label="date",
        min_value=datetime.date(2021, 1, 1),
        max_value=datetime.date(2023, 1, 1),
        key="date_input"
    )
```
hi, are there any updates on this? I'm running into the same issue.

Hi,

I would also be interested in a fix for this bug.

The problem seems to be that `is_range` is inferred based on `value`. However, when using the `session_state` it is not allowed to set `value` (at least it produces a warning). The default of `value` is `"today"`. As that is a single value, `is_range` is set to `False`.

One fix would be to just allow setting `is_range` and thus force it to the desired value. Alternatively, one could check the session state before evaluating `is_range` and use it instead of what is in `value`.

issue.title: Fix #5571

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit â€” A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
<!--
âš ï¸ BEFORE CONTRIBUTING PLEASE READ OUR CONTRIBUTING GUIDELINES!
https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/wiki/Contributing
-->

## Describe your changes

Make the behavior of `date_input` widget consistent with `st.slider` when the value is set from session_state.

We need to correctly determine that it is a range `date_input`. The main scenario we want to fix is a situation where we set range value via session_state. E.g.

```python
import streamlit as st
from datetime import date, timedelta


if "my_data_input" not in st.session_state:
    st.session_state.my_data_input = (date.today() - timedelta(days=10), date.today())

x = st.date_input(
    label="DATE INPUT LABEL",
    key="my_data_input",
)
```

This decision is not ideal, but it allows us to avoid unexpected behavior when the widget value is defined only via session_state. 

This code snippet reproduces the issue with a proposed solution. 
```python
if "my_slider" not in st.session_state:
    st.session_state.my_slider = (20, 30)

x = st.slider(
    label="SLIDER LABEL",
    value=42,
    key="my_slider",
)

st.write("VALUE:", x)
st.write(st.session_state.my_slider)
```

After the first interaction slider becomes a single slider, which is kind of expected, but confusing.
The good news is that we at least show `WidgetStateDuplicationWarning` in cases like that, so app developers should be notified about it.

I think for now we should make the behavior of `st.slider` and `st.date_input` consistent, and not buggy for most obvious cases, but as a long-term solution for the future, we should consider splitting them into pair of widgets for singe/range value. 

## GitHub Issue Link (if applicable) Closes #5571 

## Testing Plan

- Explanation of why no additional tests are needed
- Unit Tests (JS and/or Python) âœ… 
- E2E Tests
- Any manual testing needed?

---

**Contribution License Agreement**

By submitting this pull request you agree that all contributions to this project are made under the Apache 2.0 license.

body:
Hey, @dommueller, thank you for your desire to help, I didnâ€™t notice your comment when I was planning my work.
The solution that was implemented is similar to your proposal (and also the same as in a similar case with the slider).

@zoltanmihaly now if fixed, the only thing I want to note that your code snippet should work, but if you set value for session_state conditionally (otherwise any interaction will be ignored prior to session_state unconditional assignment. 

So the code snippet should look like this: 

```python
import streamlit as st
from datetime import date, timedelta


if "my_data_input" not in st.session_state:
    st.session_state.my_data_input = (date.today() - timedelta(days=10), date.today())

x = st.date_input(
    label="DATE INPUT LABEL",
    key="my_data_input",
)
```
